ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Derek, The multiplexer experiments in sharpneat are probably a good extension to the XOR problem, are easy to implement and quick to run. You might also

Hi Derek,

The multiplexer experiments in sharpneat are probably a good extension 
to the XOR problem, are easy to implement and quick to run. You might 
also consider devising some simple experiments based on memory, 
recalling sequences of symbols that sort of thing. That should be easy 
implement and fast.

Function regression is another that comes to mind. You can use a range 
of functions of varying complexity to vary the problem difficulty. The 
OneInputFunctionRegression experiment in sharpneat does this and 
contains a few different simple functions that I tried.

I think certian classes of problems are always going to be none trivial 
to implement and slow to run, e.g. control, game playing. It would be 
nice to have some reference implementations and to define a standard 
score based on performance on a fixed set of problem domains. As new 
domains are introduced we could just define a new standard that includes 
them.

>
>  It would be nice to
> have a spectrum of tasks to test a new implementation or variation out
> against, that you'd be able to run in an afternoon.


Totally agree.

Colin
